awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Linking genes to cues: How molecular mechanisms explain individual variation of adaptive plasticity to an environmental cue
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will investigate how salamanders respond to climate change by acclimating to new environments. The capacity to adjust physiological traits may be especially important for amphibians because they are one of the most threatened groups of animals on the planet. Amphibians use both terrestrial and aquatic environments and thus are particularly sensitive to environmental degradation due to climate change. Unfortunately, despite increased interest in response to climate change, we know very little about how salamander populations will fare under changing conditions. The goal of this project is to identify genes that may contribute to a salamander's ability to accommodate environmental change. This study will help determine if salamander populations can evolve an increased capacity to deal with variable environments. The study will also provide underrepresented college students the opportunity to develop independent, inquiry-based projects in amphibian biology. 

In response to climate change, organisms must adapt, acclimate, migrate, or potentially face extinction. Adaptation is a heritable evolutionary change of a population over generations. Acclimation is change that happens within the lifetime of an individual animal. If individuals vary in their capacity to acclimate, increased acclimation ability might itself evolve due to natural selection creating an adaptation of acclimation. The study will determine the capacity of individual Southern grey-cheeked salamander (Plethodon metcalfi) to adjust rates of water loss in response to temperature and humidity. Using a time-course experimental design, the study will identify differences in gene expression between individuals that acclimate and individuals that do not acclimate and identify the genes that the salamanders use to reduce rates of water loss as temperature changes. Upon identifying these genes, the study will link the activity of those genes to specific physiological responses that alter water loss. The result will be an increased understanding of the genetic basis of acclimation and adaptation to environmental cues.

por.por_cntn:
Scientific Merit

The environment imposes many stressors on organisms that threaten their survival. In response to these stressors, organisms can adjust how their body functions (i.e., physiology) to lessen the impact of a stressor, such as warm temperatures. Organisms must receive a reliable cue from the environment to ‘turn on’ specific genes that produce the desired physiological response. However, organisms often experience multiple cues from their environment, and we currently do understand how they simultaneously respond to multiple cues. Understanding these responses will improve predictions on an organism’s susceptibility to environmental change because certain stressors often occur at the same time.

In our research project, we investigated a salamander’s capacity to respond to two different stressors: temperature and humidity. We selected salamanders for our study because the southern Appalachian Mountains are home to the salamander capital of the world (i.e., more species than anywhere else), and they are predicted to be threatened by climate change. We designed a series of experiments that tested their capacity to adjust water loss rates and metabolic rate because these traits are critically important to their maintaining the most basic processes for survival. We then collected tissue samples from the skin and heart to identify the genes that are associated with physiological responses to temperature and humidity.

So far, we have learned that salamanders adjust water loss rates and metabolic rates to a single cue, temperature. We also hypothesize that these traits are changing together to a single cue due to underlying physical and chemical relationships that link them together. Therefore, as a salamander adjusts water loss rates, they are also forced to adjust metabolic rate as a consequence. We also learned that some salamanders are very flexible in their physiology, whereas other individuals never responded. These responses might represent different strategies (risky vs. conservative) for dealing with stressors. We are currently analyzing our genetic data, but linking the physiological responses to the genetic data will be critical to predicting the flexibility of individuals to environmental change.

Broader Impacts

Our project has trained graduate and undergraduate students in conducting research and presenting research at local and international conferences. We currently have two manuscripts under review from the project that also include several undergraduates as co-authors. The project also mentored students from underrepresented groups, and we provided all of our undergraduates with the skills and experiences necessary to be competitive for a career in science. The graduate (Riddell) and undergraduate students (5 students) learned to design experiments, extract genetic material from tissue, analyze results, sequence genes, conduct complex analyses on the genetic samples, and present their findings at conferences. Riddell also led a series of interactive presentations with a local high school located near Clemson, South Carolina. Over the years, Riddell and colleagues interacted with nearly 300 high school students to expose them to research, the life of a scientist, and complex topics in science, such as climate change.
